description.narrative: This project mainly contributes to results within Empowerment of human rights defenders. Results will be reported later in the Global Civsam grant period 2016-2020

Upland Human Right Based Holistic Development Program supports 31 main ethnic communities including Dara-ang, Kachin, Lahu, Akha and Karen in Chiang Mai and Chiang Rai with about 9,110 people. The rights holders are facing rights problems on personal legal status including citizenship and rights to natural resource and environment management. With personal legal status, they are limited to other rights such as occupation, education, travel, politics and that they become vulnerable to various form of exploitation including human trafficking. Without rights to natural resource management, they face an arrest by the authorities and have difficulties in conducting livelihood activities to earn their living. The program aims that the target groups are treated with justice according to their rights and they take responsibility to tackle rights related issues. The program objective is target communities, the existing network, women groups, saving group, children and youth and community leaders are capable of managing their justice and human rights issues including personal legal status and citizenship, natural resources and environment management, and gender roles leading to better quality of life. The program expects 4 results including increased capacity of local network in the management of shared issues and challenges, improved management of local people in managing and accessibility of government legal procedure and systems, increased participation of children, youth and women in local community management, and increased capacity of local people in managing their resources and rights. Major activities include capacity building, network strengthening and women empowerment. The program involves other stakeholders such as local government sectors, legal status networks and environmental networks. The focused thematic issues are basic human rights, gender roles, personal legal status and natural resource management.
